text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday morning's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The Pristina-Belgrade agreement for Kosovo Albanians, which was reached without Albanian President Sali Berisha, is seen as reducing his role as spokesman for Albanians in local and world affairs.
- Interior Minister Halit Shamata has reorganised Tirana's police to step up the fight against crime.
- Investigations into a Briton charged with sexually abusing minors have ended and his trial is to be held soon.
- Berisha and 14 parties are to meet in the afternoon on Wednesday to discuss election laws and upcoming local polls.
- The OSCE has sent a delegation to Tirana to discuss the October 20 local elections.
- After the Pristina-Belgrade agreement it is unlikely ethnic Albanians in Kosovo will boycott Serbia's November 3 elections, as threatened some time ago.
- Albanians have taken up nude bathing on some beaches.
- President Berisha is to propose a major simplification of voting procedures, and will discuss the "genocide law" and changes to political parties at a meeting this afternoon.
- European groups have voiced concern about a possible boycott of the local elections by the opposition Socialists.
- Police in the north have been ordered to take care of sheep smuggling in order to prevent foot-and-mouth disease.
- The probability of higher inflation seems to have pushed banks to increase their interest rates for savings accounts.
